componenttext: Good morning, Ghansham.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi. The weakness that you called out in Eastern Europe, is that something that felt late in the quarter or was it pretty uniform throughout the quarter?
componenttext: Hi. The weakness that you called out in Eastern Europe, is that something that felt late in the quarter or was it pretty uniform throughout the quarter?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Basically, it started in about May to develop. And it came more pronounced as the discussions about sovereign debt became more pronounced in Europe.
componenttext: Basically, it started in about May to develop. And it came more pronounced as the discussions about sovereign debt became more pronounced in Europe.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a higher level question, a big part of your strategy has been to temper idle capacity and bear the cost with the expectation that demand comes back if the economy recovers. But just given the ongoing sluggishness of the end market level, an
componenttext: Okay. And just a higher level question, a big part of your strategy has been to temper idle capacity and bear the cost with the expectation that demand comes back if the economy recovers. But just given the ongoing sluggishness of the end market level, and it looks like the bareness we've seen - actually focused on raising prices versus boosting demands. At what point do you start to permanently idling some of this capacity more so than what you've already done.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't - at this point in time, I really don't see a need for additional permanent idling. I think and as you can see, we're increasing capacities in the regions where we have significant growth. And I believe that the steps that we have taken in E
componenttext: Well, I don't - at this point in time, I really don't see a need for additional permanent idling. I think and as you can see, we're increasing capacities in the regions where we have significant growth. And I believe that the steps that we have taken in Europe and North America are appropriate, even for this period of time. Whatever we need to do in adjustments, we can do with temporary curtailments at this point in time.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks.
componenttext: Okay. Thanks.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And Ghansham, I'll add to that North America has been exporting glass to South America to balance and support their rapid growth. And we've even had Australia shipping some high quality wine bottles into China to support their growth. So we're really usin
componenttext: And Ghansham, I'll add to that North America has been exporting glass to South America to balance and support their rapid growth. And we've even had Australia shipping some high quality wine bottles into China to support their growth. So we're really using our global footprint to balance our demand and supply.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Al Kabili with Macquarie.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Al Kabili with Macquarie.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi. Thanks, guys. I just have a question on price cost. In the third quarter, it sounds like you expect the price to be flat, cost inflation to be up. So the price cost spread seems to be actually reversing and a headwind in the third quarter, if I've got
componenttext: Hi. Thanks, guys. I just have a question on price cost. In the third quarter, it sounds like you expect the price to be flat, cost inflation to be up. So the price cost spread seems to be actually reversing and a headwind in the third quarter, if I've got that right, outside of benefits you're getting from footprint actions. Can you just talk about some of the - what you see as a driver to that?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're really talking at variance at the margin here, which are relatively small. But I think one of the issues that we're seeing is because of the weaker European currency, the euro is (inaudible), and the brand to be encoded in US dollars that, of
componenttext:
Well, we're really talking at variance at the margin here, which are relatively small. But I think one of the issues that we're seeing is because of the weaker European currency, the euro is (inaudible), and the brand to be encoded in US dollars that, of course, is driving inflation and energy.
Now, you also know from previous discussions that in Europe, a lot of our contracts are basically set for a year. So we do not have the opportunity to go back and renegotiate in the middle of the year. So that is I think what we're trying to convey that there is going to be some pressure overall with regards to inflation that we have not seen in the first half of the year. We think that we will be able to keep pace with it. But certainly, it is not going to give us the expansion of margin that we have seen in the past.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks. And a follow-up question on the volumes. It sounds like Eastern Europe decelerated as the second quarter went on and your overall volumes were - a little went down - a little under 2%. Is there anything that gets you incrementally more posit
componenttext: Okay. Thanks. And a follow-up question on the volumes. It sounds like Eastern Europe decelerated as the second quarter went on and your overall volumes were - a little went down - a little under 2%. Is there anything that gets you incrementally more positive about the third quarter to assume a flat volumes year-on-year? Thanks.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I believe you have to look at the overall profile of demand. For instance, the third quarter, typically, in Europe is stronger in food and is weaker in beer. So it really also depends a little bit on how that food is distributed regionally. And I th
componenttext: Well, I believe you have to look at the overall profile of demand. For instance, the third quarter, typically, in Europe is stronger in food and is weaker in beer. So it really also depends a little bit on how that food is distributed regionally. And I think, if I recall correctly, our Eastern business - Eastern portion of the business has a somewhat higher food component than there in the Western part. So that plays a little role into this as well.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Tim Thein of Citigroup.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi. Thank you. Good morning. The question is on the year-on-year directional arrows, where - in terms of the guidance that you gave or - again, arrows on - I'm missing the slide here. But where would be - when we look on a year-over-year basis, the impact
componenttext: Hi. Thank you. Good morning. The question is on the year-on-year directional arrows, where - in terms of the guidance that you gave or - again, arrows on - I'm missing the slide here. But where would be - when we look on a year-over-year basis, the impact from the recent - the two deals that were done in the second quarter, one of which will - I guess completed in the third quarter. The full year impacts on a year-over-year basis of the Roderio [ph] acquisition. Where did those three - and I think Peru is now slated for the fourth quarter. But how do those impact the year-on-year results in terms - are they additive to earnings on a year-over-year basis?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I believe we had said that both of those acquisitions are accretive. What we are - we have not included our shipments in Argentina and the volume comparison numbers that we've given you because we feel we needed to do a comparison on a life-to-life
componenttext: Well, I believe we had said that both of those acquisitions are accretive. What we are - we have not included our shipments in Argentina and the volume comparison numbers that we've given you because we feel we needed to do a comparison on a life-to-life [ph] basis. And equally, part of the acquired businesses, especially those in Malaysia and Vietnam, will not show up in the top line. They will show up as equity income. I think our projections for the second half of the year are an upside of about a $0.01 or so from the acquisition activity.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And when you look at the - comparing the volumes, you're somewhat unique compared to others - just other rigid packager in terms of measuring volumes and tons. As you take the weight out of the bottle, how does that - if any, impact did t
componenttext: Okay. All right. And when you look at the - comparing the volumes, you're somewhat unique compared to others - just other rigid packager in terms of measuring volumes and tons. As you take the weight out of the bottle, how does that - if any, impact did that have on - is the way you state volumes in terms of tonnage?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that has, of course, an impact. And then totally, we're debating whether we should go more to a unit sales comparison as we are putting more emphasis on this going forward. But you can imagine, if you take out 30% of volume - of weight out of a wine
componenttext:
Well, that has, of course, an impact. And then totally, we're debating whether we should go more to a unit sales comparison as we are putting more emphasis on this going forward. But you can imagine, if you take out 30% of volume - of weight out of a wine bottle, eventually that's going to be reflected in your overall tonnage sales.
And I think we may need to do some work to make sure to give you greater visibility on those aspects. Because as we are pushing this more and more and on a much broader range into a variety of uses, whether it's food, whether it's beer, whether it's returnable containers, I think all of that will eventually clearly have an effect on the overall volume, whereas unit sales may in fact even increase during that period of time. So that I think is something we've got to keep in mind as we go forward. But I don't have anything readily available that has imbedded sufficiently enough to give you indication at this point.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's great. Thanks a lot.
componenttext: Yes. That's great. Thanks a lot.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Overall, with regards to volume, let me make a comment. I think if you really look at it on a global basis, our beer sales are about 40% of our total volume. And we have said several times that what we're seeing, especially in Europe and in North America,
componenttext:
Overall, with regards to volume, let me make a comment. I think if you really look at it on a global basis, our beer sales are about 40% of our total volume. And we have said several times that what we're seeing, especially in Europe and in North America, is really influenced by the fairly high rate of unemployment in young consumers at this point in time. And I think you have heard that in the conference call by the breweries as well.
I've also talked to you in the past about a shift in venue of how sales are conducted. The North America is moving away from restaurants and bars to retail. But we looked a little bit deeper into that aspect as well. And it is also quite obvious that there is also, in the retail sector, some considerable shift taking place, which we believe is temporary because of the economic situation. But still, I think it has a considerable impact. Because if you really look in the retail sales, about two-thirds of the beer retail in the United States take places in (inaudible).
And the premium beer sales and retail (inaudible) have been down by 7%. We have a much higher proportion in premium beer than we have in value beer. And I think all of those are things that are really clearly driven by available amount of money at this point in time by the consumers. And for us, that certainly has been a development that we have not seen in the past to this extent. But still, from all the evaluations and analyses we've got at this point in time, I don't think that this is really something that we'll have permanently attached to it. I think it's really a reflection of the economic situation.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of George Staphos with Bank of America/Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of George Staphos with Bank of America/Merrill Lynch.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Hi, guys. Good morning. I wanted to come back to the slide on - slide eight, the arrows/guidance slide. You never really want to be terribly precise with this. If we assume - if I heard in your answer to the prior question that acquisitions are ma
componenttext: Thanks. Hi, guys. Good morning. I wanted to come back to the slide on - slide eight, the arrows/guidance slide. You never really want to be terribly precise with this. If we assume - if I heard in your answer to the prior question that acquisitions are maybe a $0.01 or $0.02 and look at the complexion of the arrows, it seems as if overall EBIT is more or less flat in terms of what you're guiding to. And it's below the line items that could make for a down third quarter versus third quarter last year. Or do you think that acquisitions might be able to keep you flat or even higher than last year's number?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: George, we don't - it's EBIT guidance. So I don't think we can really directly respond to your question. And as a matter of fact, of course, acquisitions tend to be fairly difficult to predict when they actually are going to occur. I think we have made it
componenttext: George, we don't - it's EBIT guidance. So I don't think we can really directly respond to your question. And as a matter of fact, of course, acquisitions tend to be fairly difficult to predict when they actually are going to occur. I think we have made it very clear in the past that when we make acquisitions, we're seeking acquisitions that are accretive fairly quickly to the overall results of the company, and that they are also acquisitions that will help us in our growth trajectory going forward. So I would certainly expect that whatever we are going to do in the second half of the year and we'll complete will start to give us benefits immediately.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question, I appreciate the color there, Al. If I go back to - with slide seven, with return on capital, clearly the company's done a much better job than it has in recent years. I've covered O-I since the early '90s. It's become much more of
componenttext: Okay. Second question, I appreciate the color there, Al. If I go back to - with slide seven, with return on capital, clearly the company's done a much better job than it has in recent years. I've covered O-I since the early '90s. It's become much more of a free cash flow return story. And that's a tribute to the steps the team has been taking. Having said that, the last two years, using the, if you will, annualized 2010 results as a proxy, returns have actually been coming down again. So realizing you don’t want to go too far with capacity realignment to then prevent you from having flexibility in the future, why might there not be room for further footprint realignment, and for that matter, CapEx reduction in light of what’s been happening with return, and frankly, what’s been happening with volume and the stock this year. Thanks very much. Good luck in the quarter.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: All right. With regard to adjusting our capacity, I have mentioned in my earlier comments the start of a facility in Peru, the expansion of capacity in Rosario, the increase of capacity in New Zealand, which is going to start at the beginning of the fourt
componenttext:
All right. With regard to adjusting our capacity, I have mentioned in my earlier comments the start of a facility in Peru, the expansion of capacity in Rosario, the increase of capacity in New Zealand, which is going to start at the beginning of the fourth quarter. We have made acquisitions of additional capacity and additional footprint. I think all of those are clearly indicative that we are confident that there is growth in this business on a global basis, and that we have to be prepared for that growth.
When we did our footprint realignment, we did this at the height of the demand cycle, and the capacities that we took out at that point in time dealt with an underlying structural issue that we could correct. I believe that’s done. I think we have established the cost structure and a capacity structure that’s appropriate for the demand projections that we see.
They may not perhaps be appropriate for the next months or the months thereafter but they clearly are appropriate for what we see happening in the market in the medium to long-term. And should we - and you know we reveal every year a significant amount of furnace rebuild. So if we eventually come to a point where we see an opportunity to take out assets that are not productive or that can be replaced by other underutilized assets, we will certainly do so. But I don’t think that we are going to see any of the more concentrated correction and efforts of our asset-base that we’ve done in the past couple of years.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Rick Skidmore from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Rick Skidmore from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Al. Just to follow-up a little bit on that question, can you just talk about your capacity utilization by region or by geography?
componenttext: Thanks, Al. Just to follow-up a little bit on that question, can you just talk about your capacity utilization by region or by geography?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we are dealing, of course, right now with - in the northern hemisphere with the peak season, so the overall actual capacity utilization in North America as well as in Europe is, compared to the average for the year, at a fairly high level. I would e
componenttext:
Well, we are dealing, of course, right now with - in the northern hemisphere with the peak season, so the overall actual capacity utilization in North America as well as in Europe is, compared to the average for the year, at a fairly high level. I would expect that we will see a higher percentage capacity utilization in Asia-Pacific and in Latin America. And you heard from Ed’s comments, we’re supplementing the demands in Latin America with exports from the United States. And I think we’ll also see some exports from Europe into that.
So I would assume that what we will see in higher capacity utilization in the emerging and faster growing markets will also help advance the capacity utilization in the others. You have seen our volume in 2009 dropping off by about 10%. We all - I think we called it, 2008 was a peak capacity utilization year. So I think it’s fairly easy to calculate where our capacity is - capacity utilization is at this point in time.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just a question for Ed on the pension. Ed, can you talk about any cash contributions that you see that you might need to put into the pension plan either this year or next?
componenttext: And then maybe just a question for Ed on the pension. Ed, can you talk about any cash contributions that you see that you might need to put into the pension plan either this year or next?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It looks like we will probably stay the course with contributions $70 million, $80 million a year going into our International plans, not our US plan. And you always have to do that valuation on December 31st, but that’s what the outlook is right now.
componenttext: It looks like we will probably stay the course with contributions $70 million, $80 million a year going into our International plans, not our US plan. And you always have to do that valuation on December 31st, but that’s what the outlook is right now.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: We prepaid a little bit of 2010, would give us some flexibility this year to look at how to deploy our cash in the yearend.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks.
componenttext: Thanks.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Claudia Hueston from J.P. Morgan.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Claudia Hueston from J.P. Morgan.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi. Thanks very much. Good morning.
componenttext: Hi. Thanks very much. Good morning.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Claudia.
componenttext: Good morning, Claudia.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Even with the headwind from Venezuela, I thought your margins in Latin America recovered very nicely and are back almost close to historical levels. Can you just talk a little bit more about what drove that improvement, and then how we should think about
componenttext: Even with the headwind from Venezuela, I thought your margins in Latin America recovered very nicely and are back almost close to historical levels. Can you just talk a little bit more about what drove that improvement, and then how we should think about any potential for further expansion in margins in Latin America?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there is one obvious reason, of course, which is that overall recovery in Peru, Colombia and Brazil has been fairly rapid. They also didn’t have a steep decline even though, on our sales, we saw a fairly steep decline last year. But that wa
componenttext:
Yes, I think there is one obvious reason, of course, which is that overall recovery in Peru, Colombia and Brazil has been fairly rapid. They also didn’t have a steep decline even though, on our sales, we saw a fairly steep decline last year. But that was because of peculiarity of the market being a refillable bottom market. And so, people can easily make decisions as to whether they’re going to replace the float or not. And that’s merely has moved away. Demand is fairly strong.
You've heard me talk about several markets in Latin America being up more than 20% in volume. All of that, of course, is helping significantly. Also you will recall that at the end of last year, we did some considerable restructuring and realignment of our capacities, which of course is helping also the cost base and the cost-structure in the region significantly and giving us operational cost improvements which are reflected in the margin.
But I think the one that’s last seen under the third issue that is happening in Latin America, we are basically moving forward with a process to be much more aligned with the marketplace. With the consumer, with the customer to understand what some of the real market needs and market drivers are to get companies to consider glass really as the preferred packaging material. And we’re seeing some very good wins in that area.
And it’s particularly important to us because that would ultimately be a model that we can also apply and use in other markets to become a much more marketing-driven and marketing-oriented company.
All of those three factors, I think, are really leading to the fairly solid numbers that we have reported in the second quarter.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, chairman. I appreciate that color. And then just a little quick question, I guess. Following the acquisition you’ve done in the joint venture and on the upcoming New Zealand expansion, can you just maybe update us on how we should think about th
componenttext: Thanks, chairman. I appreciate that color. And then just a little quick question, I guess. Following the acquisition you’ve done in the joint venture and on the upcoming New Zealand expansion, can you just maybe update us on how we should think about the mix of business in the Asia-Pacific region between Australia, New Zealand, and then the more emerging developing Asia?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I’d say Australia and New Zealand still is the preponderance of our business, of course, in the region. But with the addition of the plants that we have acquired, as well as further targeted acquisitions that we want to make, I think you will see a fair
componenttext:
I’d say Australia and New Zealand still is the preponderance of our business, of course, in the region. But with the addition of the plants that we have acquired, as well as further targeted acquisitions that we want to make, I think you will see a fairly rapid shift in Asia-Pacific to perhaps a more balanced volume picture between Australia and New Zealand and Southeast Asia, and China in particular.
Now, from a margin stand point, I think it is quite clear. We have said in the past that the Chinese margins tend to be at the lower end. So that is not necessarily going to really shift the importance from Australia and New Zealand still as a significant profit contributor.
But I believe, looking into the future, certainly the volume increases that we expect out of China will also help us overall in our cost structure as well in the increase of margins in the long term.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks.
componenttext: Okay, thanks.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from line of Chris Manuel from KeyBanc.
componenttext: And your next question is from line of Chris Manuel from KeyBanc.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, gentlemen.
componenttext: Good morning, gentlemen.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning.
componenttext: Good morning.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First is, both in your press release and in your slide deck, you highlight price responsiveness to import cost, which I guess I understand, but the second component being demand trends. Can you maybe expand on that a little bit, is
componenttext: A couple of questions. First is, both in your press release and in your slide deck, you highlight price responsiveness to import cost, which I guess I understand, but the second component being demand trends. Can you maybe expand on that a little bit, is there something changing in the competitive landscape that’s requiring you to go out and be - make adjustments in relation to where demand is at as well? Or I guess a little more color there.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think a lot of that has already happened in the past year and a half. I just saw some statistics on Europe. There are, as members of the European Glass Federation, 156 glass clans in Europe. So it’s, of course, a much more diverse scenario. And what w
componenttext:
I think a lot of that has already happened in the past year and a half. I just saw some statistics on Europe. There are, as members of the European Glass Federation, 156 glass clans in Europe. So it’s, of course, a much more diverse scenario. And what we very often find is that these glass operations have a local or limited regional presence and very often those manufactures really have no alternative but try to run the facilities at a full rate because it’s the only operations they have. And that's where we are seeing, from time-to-time, some pressure.
When they're assured, there're certain volumes and certain periods of time they tend to go to adjoining or adjacencies, which for them are export markets, even if they're within the same country. But if they are outside of the 300-kilometer range, they look at it as an export market. And that is what we are referring to that we have a point Rick said that really we need to address at a particular point in time. And I don't think that that, overall, is going to negatively impact our margins and our profitability profile. So we have to be responsive to those because otherwise they might potentially impact our profitability because it was two months off.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So Ed, that's a new component that I think I haven't seen in the last few press releases as a component. So I guess am I reading this correctly in thinking of - I know you said this is an ongoing issue that's been going on for a while. But it seems
componenttext: Okay. So Ed, that's a new component that I think I haven't seen in the last few press releases as a component. So I guess am I reading this correctly in thinking of - I know you said this is an ongoing issue that's been going on for a while. But it seems to be somewhat intensifying. And other certain regions, you mentioned Europe, given that beer volumes are relatively weak that had somewhat intensified just more recently.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you have got to be astute to what's happening if we say the demand in Eastern Europe has weakened. Eastern Europe typically is a low cost manufacturing region, so that what we will find as some competitors from Eastern Europe will fight to m
componenttext: Well, I think you have got to be astute to what's happening if we say the demand in Eastern Europe has weakened. Eastern Europe typically is a low cost manufacturing region, so that what we will find as some competitors from Eastern Europe will fight to move their volume then into Western Europe, and that will, of course, then request us and require us to be reactive.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And I hate to keep coming back to this because I think it's been asked two or three or four times already. But the volume trajectory as we go forward, I noticed inside your slide eight and your slide deck you talked about sales volum
componenttext:
Okay. That's helpful. And I hate to keep coming back to this because I think it's been asked two or three or four times already. But the volume trajectory as we go forward, I noticed inside your slide eight and your slide deck you talked about sales volume being flat 3Q to 3Q and flat for the full year. But seeing a pullback, particularly later in the quarter, and I think you mentioned North America and Europe for beer, the comps get more difficult as the year goes on that you're laughing. I think you were - 2Q comp you were laughing. It we're down 12% last year, and it was only down 6%. And that's implying some acceleration through the back half of the year when the trend is getting a little worse.
What gives you that confidence? I know you mentioned mix earlier. But what gives you confidence that this trajectory is going to change from what you've seen in May and June to the balance of the year to reverse that.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we certainly see the trends in the emerging regions strengthening. And you've seen and heard some of the impressive growth rates that we're seeing there. I believe that the real uncertainty at this point in time is what's really going to happen to b
componenttext:
Well, we certainly see the trends in the emerging regions strengthening. And you've seen and heard some of the impressive growth rates that we're seeing there. I believe that the real uncertainty at this point in time is what's really going to happen to beer and beer consumption. And there is - perhaps the breweries can give you a much better view of what they expect. But I saw a comment recently from (inaudible) where they felt that they would eventually go back to 1% or 2% growth again.
And I think we've got to, of course, play it by ear. But I believe that the numbers that we're looking at, at this point in time would lead us to believe that we can remain fairly stable with what we have seen in the first half of this year and stay on top of things. Because when you really look at the overall profile from the first quarter to the second quarter through the first - or the fourth quarter of last year, you saw a continuing improvement. And that continued also in the first quarter of this year, and with the exception of the contractual conclusions and discussions that we had in the United States. Still, our underlying volume in the rest of the world is still showing a positive comparison.
So we've got to keep that in mind that when we look at O-I, we're not necessarily looking at the underlying market sense because we took a decision - a significant decision with regards to North America, which may be impacting the overall comparison numbers quite a bit.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you for the help.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you for the help.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: All right.
componenttext: All right.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line Peter Ruschmeier with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line Peter Ruschmeier with Barclays.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Al, I was curious if you could comment on the Chinese glass market. Do you believe the sellers' preferences in China have more reasonable expectations today than they did a year ago? And can you comment on that?
componenttext: Thank you. Good morning. Al, I was curious if you could comment on the Chinese glass market. Do you believe the sellers' preferences in China have more reasonable expectations today than they did a year ago? And can you comment on that?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I believe that, overall, when I look at the M&A pipeline, it certainly filled up quite a bit over the last six or eight months. And that includes also China. I believe that some of the expectations have become a little bit more normalized. And I think opp
componenttext: I believe that, overall, when I look at the M&A pipeline, it certainly filled up quite a bit over the last six or eight months. And that includes also China. I believe that some of the expectations have become a little bit more normalized. And I think opportunities still abound for fulfilling our strategy that we talked to you about at our investor conference in early March. I certainly don't see anything that would say, "Well, base conditions have dramatically changed from that." And so, I think we can still execute on that strategy. And I think also we will find sufficient targets that have - buys expectations that will allow us to make those acquisitions accretive.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess on a related point, has your investment in China so far given you any new insights to the middle market in particular that you targeted growing into, maybe you can speak to the competitive landscape, and maybe the risks and opportunities you
componenttext: Okay. I guess on a related point, has your investment in China so far given you any new insights to the middle market in particular that you targeted growing into, maybe you can speak to the competitive landscape, and maybe the risks and opportunities you see as you try to enter that middle market?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that one of the clear things that we've seen is that the demand growth is the greatest in the low-cost to mid-cost segments of consumer products. We also were always looking, of course, what's happening in the premium brands. But very often,
componenttext:
Yes. I think that one of the clear things that we've seen is that the demand growth is the greatest in the low-cost to mid-cost segments of consumer products. We also were always looking, of course, what's happening in the premium brands. But very often, that only really represents 5% to 8% of the market.
If you really look at the large volume component, it's still growing at double-digit rates across the board. And that is fairly impressive. Especially when you look at the overall demand in China, it really means you have to constantly add new capacity to keep up with the demand. And we were seeing some of that in the 2004 to 2008 range when a lot of new entrants were coming into the market and building these facilities.
But it's also becoming apparent that China is going through a consolidation phase in the customer base as well. And so, I believe companies that are able to have a more holistic approach to the market and cross regional approach within China to the market, they will do very well in this environment.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And really last and I'll turn it over, just sticking on the same theme, anymore observations about the asset quality in China and business practices, and the types of changes you may look to employ within those operations?
componenttext: Okay. And really last and I'll turn it over, just sticking on the same theme, anymore observations about the asset quality in China and business practices, and the types of changes you may look to employ within those operations?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, very often, what we see are facilities that have been built, as I said, within the last four or five years. So they're fairly new facilities. Housekeeping is selling very good. I just recently visited the facility that we acquired in Tiangin [ph] in
componenttext:
Well, very often, what we see are facilities that have been built, as I said, within the last four or five years. So they're fairly new facilities. Housekeeping is selling very good. I just recently visited the facility that we acquired in Tiangin [ph] in China. And I was quite impressed with what I saw. I believe that clearly, typically, we would find a much higher level of labor and employment rate in those facilities.
But still, on a cost comparison base, labor is still much more affordable than we would find in the North American or European markets. And overall, of course, the cost base as well as their overall design of facilities gives us some insight that we can possibly use in other regions of the world as well to get a more attractive profile with regards to capital needs for expansions and for replacement alternative.

componenttextpreview: Well, Mark, I mean if you really look at it, we're about - what - was it 1.7% or 1.8% short. That equates on the quarter to about a day of sales out of 63 days. So I think trying to be too specific in trying to read the trends of perhaps a weakening at th
componenttext:
Well, Mark, I mean if you really look at it, we're about - what - was it 1.7% or 1.8% short. That equates on the quarter to about a day of sales out of 63 days. So I think trying to be too specific in trying to read the trends of perhaps a weakening at the end of quarter, which by the way, for many people, still is also on our customer side at the end of the quarter. So we may have had a much stronger emphasis on balance sheet items, on inventories.
It's very difficult to really measure that. I think trying to describe a pattern or a trend to a month or two, or quarter in this business given the huge upheaval that we've seen economically and in the overall employment levels is extremely difficult.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, all right. I mean that's fair, Al. Then, just a little longer term, you talked a little bit about that three-year plan that you laid out for us this spring. I wondered, given what you're seeing in the developed markets, in North America and Europe, w
componenttext: Yes, all right. I mean that's fair, Al. Then, just a little longer term, you talked a little bit about that three-year plan that you laid out for us this spring. I wondered, given what you're seeing in the developed markets, in North America and Europe, whether there're any changes that you would anticipate in that plan. You already to M&A potential there in the emerging markets, no need to change there. But I wondered in terms of the organic growth that you might have been forecasting in the developed markets, whether that is starting to change for you.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Excuse. No, I think the biggest change that we have seen since the first quarter of this year or since we put the plan together was really towards the end of last year. It's really the exchange rate. And you see that reflected at virtually all of the shor
componenttext:
Excuse. No, I think the biggest change that we have seen since the first quarter of this year or since we put the plan together was really towards the end of last year. It's really the exchange rate. And you see that reflected at virtually all of the shortfalls that we show with regards to overall sales compared to last year is really exchange rate driven. And that's going to be a continuing issue for us, either through the upside or through the downside as almost 75% to 80% of our volume is going to be in currencies outside of the US dollar region.
And I believe that that, however, is not going to impact our strategy because we typically also then manufacture in those regions. So the benefit of that currency in the cost structure also accrues to us. But it's, of course, in the conversion then of the sale as well as in the conversion of the profits into US dollars where we will see some variations depending on what's happening in exchange rate.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Angela and I will be your conference operator. At this time I would like to welcome everyone to the O-I third quarter 2010 earnings conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the spe
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Angela and I will be your conference operator. At this time I would like to welcome everyone to the O-I third quarter 2010 earnings conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers’ remarks, there will be a question-and-answer session. (Operator instructions)
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Ed White, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Angela. Good morning and welcome everyone to O-I’s Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. I am joined today by Al Stroucken, our Chairman and CEO; John Haudrich, Vice President of Finance and several other members of our senior manageme
componenttext:
Thank you, Angela. Good morning and welcome everyone to O-I’s Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. I am joined today by Al Stroucken, our Chairman and CEO; John Haudrich, Vice President of Finance and several other members of our senior management team.
Today, we will discuss key business developments in the quarter, review our financial results, and discuss future trends affecting our business. Following our prepared remarks, we’ll host a question-and-answer session. Presentation materials for this earnings call are also being simulcast from the company’s Web site at o-i.com.
Please review the Safe Harbor comments and disclosure of our use of non-GAAP financial measures included in those materials. Unless otherwise noted, the financial results we are presenting today relate to adjusted net earnings, which exclude certain items that management considers not representative of ongoing operations. A reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP earnings can be found in our earnings press release and in the appendix to this presentation.
I will now turn the call over to Al, who will start on chart two.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed and good morning. Before I discuss the results of the third quarter, I would like to spend a few minutes on the recent developments with our operations in Venezuela. On Monday, President Hugo Chavez announced his intents to expropriate O-I
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed and good morning. Before I discuss the results of the third quarter, I would like to spend a few minutes on the recent developments with our operations in Venezuela. On Monday, President Hugo Chavez announced his intents to expropriate O-I’s facilities in Venezuela. Subsequently, a formal decree was issued by the Venezuelan government.
First, I want to personally thank all our employees in Venezuela for their continued dedication to O-I during these difficult and uncertain times. Glass making is a highly specialized and complex industry, and plants require a great deal of expertise to run safely and effectively.
We have been in constant contact with our facility managers to ensure a safe operating environment for all of our employees, and we continue to operate the facilities to ensure we service our customers whose products meet the food and beverage needs of the Venezuelan people.
This is a very fluid situation with many uncertainties. Clearly, we are very disappointed with these developments after successfully operating in Venezuela for over 50 years.
We are working diligently to protect the interests of our employees, customers and shareholders, and we will provide timely updates as we gain a better understanding of the situation and can articulate our next steps. Ed will review a few of the financial matters associated with this situation shortly.
Now, turning to third quarter results, earnings were $0.90 per share in the third quarter of 2010. Excluding the impact of currency translation, O-I earned $0.94 per share. So, on a currency neutral basis, earnings were basically in line with prior year results.
Business conditions in the third quarter were consistent with those in the first half of 2010. Strong growth continued in the emerging markets, especially in South America and we capitalized on strategic opportunities to expand on those attractive regions.
Glass demand by the brewers remained sluggish in the mature markets, but we saw a positive growth in the beer across the emerging markets as well as in food, wine, and spirit and juice categories on a worldwide basis.
Globally, our shipments were down 2.4% from the prior year. Those mainly reflected lower volumes resulting from contract renegotiations that went into effect in 2010. If you adjust for the impact of those contracts, shipments were up 1% from last year which is more indicative of consumer demand trends.
Like last quarter, a favorable regional sales mix in our fast growing and profitable South American operations mostly offset the earnings impact of lower global shipments. While cost inflation was negligible in the first half of 2010, we did incur a higher input costs in the third quarter.
In addition, manufacturing costs in the quarter increased due to the start-up of two new furnaces in South America and the completion of our realignment activities in North America. These activities impacted third quarter results, but the operational improvements will of course benefit future earnings.
Free cash flow in the quarter was $75 million, which reflects seasonal working capital trends in our industry. We made additional progress on the execution of our strategic priorities this quarter.
We further expanded our presence in South America through our acquisition of CIV, the leading glassmaker in Northern Brazil. This acquisition added three plants in one of Brazil’s fastest growing regions.
Yesterday, we also announced the acquisition of a single plant operation near Guangdong, China and this is consistent with our strategy to grow in one of the world’s largest consumer markets.
We successfully completed a Eurobond offering in the quarter to help ensure that we maintain the financial flexibility we need to pursue additional strategic activities.
Looking to the fourth quarter, we expect prices will remain stable. We anticipate demand in most end used categories to improve over the prior year with the likely exception of shipments to beer customers in mature markets. We expect to see increased sales in South America, as a result of our new production capacity and recent acquisitions.
Overall, operating rates should be higher than in the fourth quarter of last year. Although, it’s too early to tell for sure, it is likely that the recent developments in Venezuela will negatively impact results in the fourth quarter.
Now, let’s review our operating performance on chart three. Here we show segment operating profit and margins for the company as well as for each of our four regions.
Overall segment operating profit was $299 million and margins exceeded 17% of sale. Adjusted to reflect prior year currency exchange rates segment profit was $308 million, so on the like-for-like basis, quarterly earnings declined $9 million from last year reflecting lower sales volume and additional cost inflation.
Now, let’s review regional trends beginning with Europe. Operating profit was $113 million in the third quarter, on a like-for-like basis profit was $123 million, down $5 million from the prior year. Consistent with the outlook provided during our last earnings call, third quarter selling prices were down modestly from 2009.
Total third quarter European shipments increased slightly from the prior year. Shipments were nearly up 5% across most of Western Europe, which represented more than 80% of our European volumes.
Well, glass demand for the beer segment remained sluggish. We saw a strong demand in other end-use categories. However, the Netherlands, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were down double digits due to lower food and beer shipments. In particular, Eastern Europe continued to struggle with challenging market conditions following the European financial crisis.
Given slightly higher overall shipments and the very low inventory level entering the quarter, capacity utilization in the third quarter increased from the prior year. Year-to-date temporary curtailments in Europe represented about 5% of total capacity, down significantly from the prior year.
In North America, our operating profit was $71 million in the quarter, down $12 million from last year. North American shipments were down more than 10% from the third quarter of 2009, continuing the trends that we have seen all year.
Higher margins, however, again mostly offset the impact of lower sales volumes. Lower shipments in the region were attributable to the renegotiation of several key customer contracts at the end of 2009, as well as a continued weak U.S. beer consumption, which was down 1% to 2% in the third quarter. However, trends have slightly improved in recent months compared to earlier this year.
Glass shipment trends have gradually improved in recent month, as well as consumption of premium brands has picked up relative to sub-premium brands, and we also saw a continued improvement in other end-use categories such as food and wine.
We completed our footprint realignment efforts in North America during the third quarter and realigned our business mix with our remaining manufacturing network.
As a result, we incurred additional costs during the third quarter that accounted for most of the shortfall in regional earnings over 2009 level. But this restructured footprint should drive improved earnings going forward. We continue to expect that our full year 2010 North American profits will meet or exceed prior year results.
Despite the recent developments in Venezuela, we remained very encouraged about the future of South America. In fact, our South American region continues to be our top performer with operating profits of $77 million in the third quarter as margins improved to 26%.
On a currency neutral basis, profits were $79 million up $15 million from the prior year. Strong shipments continued across all end-use markets, especially beer driven by new product introductions. In fact, volume was up around 20% in South America, excluding Venezuela which was flat over the prior year.
To meet growing demand in the region, we began production at our nearly constructed furnaces in Argentina and in Peru. These assets are already operating at best-in-class production levels.
Strong growth also led to higher production and capacity utilization rates in South America. Our acquisition of CIV in the third quarter will further boost production. And Ed will review more details on that acquisition in a minute.
Our Asia-Pacific region reported third quarter operating profit of $38 million. On a like-for-like basis, profits were $35 million, down from $42 million last year. While higher prices essentially offset cost inflation this quarter, volumes were down mid single-digits from last year.
Like Europe, Asia-Pac volume trends vary by country. Starting in Australia, glass volumes were down, the strong Australian dollar which is now at parity with U.S. dollar created a cost disadvantage for Australian wine exports.
In addition, some of our beer business traded hands as a competitor added glass capacity earlier this year. We have one new business, but it will take several months for O-I to backfill the lost volume.
In China, our shipments were boost by the July acquisition of our new plant in Sichuan. Yesterday, we announced the acquisition of a majority interest in an additional plant near Guangdong, China for $29 million.
This acquisition complements O-I’s existing operations in Guangdong, China’s fourth large glass market as a province, and we are pushing the upper limit of capacity in our manufacturing systems in China which underscores the needs for further acquisitions and investments in the future to keep up with the growth in this market.
We are pleased with the progress at our new joint venture in Malaysia and Vietnam after only two full months productivity rates have increased by about 15 percentage points. While continuing to integrate O-I’s extensive knowledge of global manufacturing processes we see additional opportunities to increase the profitability of this joint venture.
Finally, we began production at our new furnace in New Zeeland in October. We look forward to updating you on our progress for these strategic activities in more detail in late coming quarters.
Globally, market conditions remained consistent with the first half of 2010. Glass demand for beer in mature markets remained down likely due to persistent unemployment across key demographics for beer customers. Emerging market growth was strong, and most end-use categories in the mature markets have been growing as those economies gradually recover.
I’ll discuss our demand trends in greater detail on chart four. With our year-to-date shipments down 1.3% I heard some concern that glass is facing structural market challenges.
Now, let me provide you some details why I do not believe that that is the case. We have illustrated our year-to-date demand growth by key end-use categories on this chart.
As you can see, O-I’s glass shipments for spirits and wine, as well as beer in emerging markets improved between 5% and 13% from last year, while food was up about 2% or rather our glass shipments for beer in the developed markets were down more than 11% from last year. As a result of this sizable decline, our total shipments were down slightly from last year in total.
So, the significant decline in glass volume for beer mostly reflected our price over volume strategy over the past few years and not any large scale industry shift away from beer and glass bottles. As we raised prices to repair our margins in recent years, we knew we would surrender some volume, and that is now fully reflected in our 2010 shipment trends.
This trade-off has clearly improved our financial performance since we initiated this strategy several years ago. The orange bar on the chart demonstrate our volumes, excluding the impact of these pricing actions, limited to beer customers in the U.S., Europe and Australia.
Adjusted for pricing action effects, our shipments to beer customers were down 3.3% in the mature markets, which was generally in line with beer consumption trends. For example, consumption has declined so far this year by about 3% in Western Europe, 2% in the United States, and 1% in Australia.
While beer glass volumes are down, we have been working with a number of our multinational customers in other end-use categories to earn new business and we’re encouraged by these developments.
Therefore, excluding the impact of our pricing actions, O-I’s global shipments were up 1.8% year-to-date, and this growth rate is a bit lower than we expected earlier this year and it just shows that like many others, we have not been great at predicting the immediate future in this economic environment. However, I see no structural issues in the glass business. In fact, our business trends are generally favorable across most regions and end-uses.
Now, I will turn the call back over to Ed.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Al. Now, I will discuss Venezuela along with our business outlook at the end of my prepared remarks. Let me begin with our financial review with the reconciliations for sales, operating profit and EPS on chart five.Segment sales decreased $135 mi
componenttext:
Thanks Al. Now, I will discuss Venezuela along with our business outlook at the end of my prepared remarks. Let me begin with our financial review with the reconciliations for sales, operating profit and EPS on chart five.
Segment sales decreased $135 million to $1.7 billion in the third quarter of 2010. As expected, price and product mix were essentially flat with the prior year. As we’ve seen all year, cost pass-through provisions in our North American customer contracts resulted in a small impact on sales and had a negligible effect on operating profit.
Moving to sales volume on the following line, glass shipments in tons were 2.4% below the prior year on a global basis, reducing sales by $40 million. These sales figures include the benefit of recent acquisitions, which added approximately 1% to our volumes.
Finally, the stronger U.S. dollar reduced our top line by $90 million in the third quarter. This impact was due to a weaker euro and the Venezuela bolivar devaluation, partially offset by stronger currencies in other countries. While the euro was rallied in recent months, it was still weaker than the U.S. dollar compared to the average of the third quarter 2009.
Moving over to segment operating profit, the third quarter was $299 million, down $18 million from the same period in 2009. Since price and product mix were flat, they had no year-over-year impact on operating profit. Lower sales volumes only slightly impacted operating profit due to improved regional mix given strong growth of higher margin business in South America. Manufacturing and delivery costs increased $21 million.
We incurred cost inflation of $26 million and the startup costs penalties that Al mentioned. These were partially offset by incremental footprint savings and higher operating rates. Results benefited $15 million from other operating items as we reduced discretionary spending and benefited from a few one-time items.
Finally, currency translation reduced operating profit by $9 million in the third quarter, mostly due to a weaker euro. Finishing with the EPS reconciliation, our adjusted net income was $0.90 per share in the quarter, down $0.05 from the prior year. As we just discussed, operating profit was down $0.07 from last year. However, earnings did benefit from favorable non-operating items.
Our effective tax rate was lower than last year, reflecting our current regional earnings mix. Also EPS benefited from a lower share count after repurchasing 6 million shares in the first half of the year.
Corporate costs were up from last year due to higher non-cash pension expense. This was partially offset by cost reduction efforts. Likewise, we’ve reduced management incentive compensation expense to reflect current financial results.
One comment on GAAP EPS. We incurred approximately $9 million of Note 1 charges in the third quarter, related to one-time cost and purchase price accounting associated with our recent acquisitions. Free cash flow in the third quarter was $75 million. As a result, the company is free cash flow positive year-to-date.
Chart six illustrates our year-over-year reconciliation. The decline in free cash flow generation is mostly attributed to working capital and CapEx. Working capital was a $143 million greater use of cash in the first nine months of 2010. The difference is due to the significant inventory reductions we took last year that did not repeat at the same level in 2010.
Next, capital expenditures were $198 million higher through September 2010. This difference was largely due to timing as 2009 CapEx was mostly deferred until the fourth quarter, and 2010 spending has been more evenly distributed across the year. Importantly, the fourth quarter 2009 spending spike will not repeat in 2010.
Let’s move to chart seven for more detail on our balance sheet and several strategic initiatives that we completed in the third quarter. On September 30, 2010, cash was $700 million which included about $40 million in Venezuela.
Total debt at the end of the quarter was $4.3 billion. Net debt was $3.6 billion, which increased by $826 million from the second quarter, primarily to fund acquisitions.
Our net debt to EBITDA ratio was 2.8 times at September 30, higher than our second quarter ratio of 2.2 times, again reflecting our acquisitions in the third quarter. But the ratio was still within our target leverage range between two and three times.
Third quarter restructuring payments were higher than the second quarter, reflecting the advancement of our North American realignment project. Capital expenditures totaled $155 million in the quarter, which was similar to our second quarter level.
Our 2010 capital expenditures approximate $500 million. We have pulled back on some projects in the fourth quarter, but the weaker U.S. dollar and incremental capital on new acquisitions are offsetting this lower activity.
As illustrated on the right, most of our CapEx this year is for maintenance project and it’s within our 80% to 85% range of depreciation. The remaining capital is focused on our North American restructuring program and growth initiatives. The growth investments are concentrated in South America and Asia Pacific to keep up with increased demand. Overall, we believe our capital expenditures are prudent and in line with our profitable growth strategies.
Also on the right, you can see our two largest strategic activities completed in the third quarter. The first is our acquisition of CIV in northeast Brazil. Brazil represents the largest economy in glass container market in South America, so it is key for O-I.
We already have a robust business and experienced management team in the southern region of the company. The CIV acquisition will provide a strong complement to our current franchise in Brazil, and will allow us to serve many existing and new customers for expanding their operations in the Northeast.
CIV’s three facilities will increase O-I’s capacity in Brazil by 50%. O-I’s total purchase price for CIV was $603 million, which included approximately $140 million for future tax benefits. The purchase price reflects a 5.8 times EBITDA multiple based on 2011 forecasted EBITDA of $80 million.
We expect that the CIV acquisition will be accretive to earnings per share in 2011, and the return on investment of this business is well above O-I’s cost of capital.
The second strategic initiative was in early September. We issued €500 million of 10 year senior notes at an interest rate of 6.75%. We are pleased that these bonds have been the most favorably priced offering in the European high yield markets so far this year.
In addition to an attractive coupon rate and a tax-efficient structure, greater euro denominated interest expense is a natural currency hedge for our European properties. The proceeds of the euro bonds will enable further strategic and profitable growth.
Turning to chart eight; you see our business outlook for the fourth quarter of 2010, we have provided the usual directional guidance on the key business drivers affecting earnings and cash flow. All trends are on a year-over-year basis comparing expected fourth quarter 2010 performance with the same period in 2009.
As Al mentioned, the development in Venezuela will likely negatively impact our fourth quarter results. However, the situation is very fluid, so our outlook does not include any potential impact from Venezuela.
Now let me review each of the factors. Price and product mix, similar to the third quarter, we expect prices in the fourth quarter to be flat with prior year levels. Sales volume, clearly, we have struggled to identify the turning point with beer demand in mature markets.
Beer consumption remains sluggish and has not improved significantly, despite promotional efforts by our customers. Hence, we anticipate fourth quarter glass demand for beer in the U.S. and Europe will remain down from the prior year. However, we expect continued year-over-year growth in all other end-use categories.
The net effect of these two trends is difficult to project. Depending on their relative movement, we can foresee fourth quarter sales volumes being 2% above or below prior year levels.
Manufacturing and delivery, higher capacity utilization should result in lower manufacturing and delivery costs compared to last year. Footprint savings should mostly offset cost inflation that is expected to be comparable to third quarter levels.
Non-operating costs, corporate costs will be higher than the fourth quarter of last year, mostly reflecting additional pension expense which we’ve seen every quarter in 2010. Also, net interest expense will increase approximately $15 million on a year-over-year basis in the fourth quarter due to higher debt to fund acquisitions.
Furthermore, we are taking steps to curtail our spending plans given lower than anticipated volumes in 2010. We have evaluated corporate expense, restructuring payments and working capital investments. We expect to reduce spending in these categories by $20 to $30 million from our original expectations.
Let me wrap up with a discussion on Venezuela. As I mentioned, the financial implications of expropriation remain unclear. Given this lack of clarity, I will provide some information about our Venezuelan operations to give you a sense of their scope relative to O-I in total. First, we’ve been operating in Venezuela for over 50 years serving the country’s food and beverage industry.
I’d like to take the opportunity to thank the more than 1,000 employees at the two plants for all their hard work and dedication during these difficult times. O-I has a 75% ownership interest in our Venezuelan operations with the remaining ownership held by a minority partner. Year-to-date, Venezuela accounted for approximately 3% of O-I global sales volume. The country represented just under 5% of segment operating profits and adjusted net earnings.
Finally, O-I’s net assets in Venezuela approximated 4% of O-I’s total net assets as of September 30. We intend to provide regular and timely updates on this situation as information becomes available.
Now, I’ll turn it back to Al for chart nine.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ed. Let me close with some comments on the financial targets that we introduced at our Investor Day in March of this year. Chart nine highlights our net sales and segment operating profit margin goals for 2012.If you recall, we indicated our sal
componenttext:
Thanks, Ed. Let me close with some comments on the financial targets that we introduced at our Investor Day in March of this year. Chart nine highlights our net sales and segment operating profit margin goals for 2012.
If you recall, we indicated our sales will grow between $9 billion and $9.5 billion and our global segment operating profit margins will expand to 16% to 18% by the end of this three-year period, and we continue to expect that this growth will be achieved equally through a recovering market place and mergers and acquisitions.
Now, that we are almost a third of the way into this three-year period, we can say that we are pleased with our M&A progress. Through the third quarter, we have made three high quality acquisitions and more importantly our M&A pipeline remains full as we work to close more deals in the upcoming quarters.
On the other hand, the rate of our overall market recovery has been inconsistent, robust in South America and China, but slower than anticipated in the mature markets. That said, we remain optimistic that a recovering marketplace in both Europe and North America should favorably impact the premium end-use segments that we serve. It is just going to take more time than we had originally expected, but it’s still likely to be achieved within our original three-year horizon.
As the developments in Venezuela over the past few days show, events can change rapidly, but based on today’s perspective, we remain confident that we are on the trajectory to reach our three year target. Furthermore, O-I’s strategic priorities remain unchanged to support those objectives.
Now, I will ask the operator to open the line for your questions. Thank you.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions) And your first question is from the line of Tim Thein with Citigroup.
componenttext: (Operator instructions) And your first question is from the line of Tim Thein with Citigroup.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thank you, good morning. First question is I know it’s kind of early days here, but as you look out into the contract negotiations in Europe, I’m curious as to any kind of early read you can give into 2011. I know a competitor of yours had stated
componenttext: Hi, thank you, good morning. First question is I know it’s kind of early days here, but as you look out into the contract negotiations in Europe, I’m curious as to any kind of early read you can give into 2011. I know a competitor of yours had stated that they expect to be able to offset any cost inflation into 2011, (inaudible) was their initial read, but I’m curious given your commentary about how pricing did trail off in the quarter, do you have similar expectations into 2011 in Europe?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have similar expectations as well. We think that clearly and already in the course of this year as well, our ability and pricing was really tracking with what was happening in inflation, and in the beginning of the year of course, we were still se
componenttext:
Yes, we have similar expectations as well. We think that clearly and already in the course of this year as well, our ability and pricing was really tracking with what was happening in inflation, and in the beginning of the year of course, we were still seeing some benefits of the deflation that was happening in the course of last year.
But as we went through the third quarter, in particular, we saw that the impact of the U.S. dollar which at that point in time was higher than the previous year was impacting the price of brand fruit, which is quoted in U.S. dollars and the conversion to euros, and it was causing inflationary pressure.
I think we also are looking at what’s going to happen in the supply and demand situation with regard to soda ash, which of course is a considerable cost driver. I think everybody in the industry are seeing the same pressures and therefore I believe we will see a continued approach to the marketplace that is reflective of making sure that we pass-through cost inflation appropriately to maintain our margins.

componenttext: On the productivity side, what we said is you’ve got flowing through their footprint and I think as we’ve talked about, it was about $15 million to $18 million. You had the start-up penalties where you have to light the furnace, it takes a month for the sand to get hot enough to be making glass, and you had that across four factories which was a penalty, and then I’m going to say inflation was, where we talked about that being in the 20 to 25 range.

componenttext: Those were kind of the moving parts, George on that. In terms of productivity itself, obviously in run rates, North America is at the low end of the range in the 80, 85 range. headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: That segues to my next question which is, given the relatively lower operating rates in North America, given the challenges you said you’ve had, and we don’t blame yet been a tough market. But nonetheless in projecting when the inflection point comes
componenttext: That segues to my next question which is, given the relatively lower operating rates in North America, given the challenges you said you’ve had, and we don’t blame yet been a tough market. But nonetheless in projecting when the inflection point comes in beer, given that it was a tougher market thus far as the growth expansion plans haven’t led yet to a commensurate moving your equity price. Are there any thoughts perhaps in further optimizing your asset base and your spending for that matter in your more mature markets?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: When we talk about operating rates in North America, of course, we still had in the first half of the year capacity that we haven’t taken out. So you have to take that into consideration as well. I think we have taken the steps that are necessary to adj
componenttext:
When we talk about operating rates in North America, of course, we still had in the first half of the year capacity that we haven’t taken out. So you have to take that into consideration as well. I think we have taken the steps that are necessary to adjust to the volume loss that we’ve seen through our pricing actions in late last year, and I think that is accomplished at this point in time. I believe that if I really look at my operating rates across the world we are at this point in time at a level where we can still through temporary steps adjust our capacity through the demand levels more appropriately.
I believe as well that we need to have some flex through the upside if the demand picks up because the worst thing we could do is shutdown the furnace permanently and then half a year from now need one. You can imagine that that does not lead to a very good return on investment. So, I think we have taken the steps that are necessary for the infrastructure to be appropriately designed for the demand that we are seeing at this point in time, and we have sufficient flex through the upside to really be able to partake some of this growth without immediate demand or significant demand on capital.

So, I think we’ve most probably done some investments that is going to benefit us already next year and would not require additional investment there.

componenttext: Yes, it does. The traditional comment about same-store sales, we don’t think it’s working for us because we’re consciously reducing the stores in mature markets and we’re growing in the growth markets. So, if you look back at the strategic footprint initiative and our M&A, we’ve shutdown eight factories over the last three years in North America and Europe, and we’ve acquired eight factories in Asia, Southeast Asia and South America. So, what we’re trying to do is put them together as you can talk about it, our global realignment moving forward.
