I was thinking it was more China, and therefore it looks like you’re getting more of it in a more establish market for you. Secondly, do you need more acquisitions to get to that level or is your footprint big enough to get to your 2012 goals?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we said in the beginning of this year, basically half of our growth is going to come from M&A and half from organic growth, and clearly what we’ve done in M&A, it’s not yet up to that 50% number, so there is still going to be more acquisitions that
componenttext: As we said in the beginning of this year, basically half of our growth is going to come from M&A and half from organic growth, and clearly what we’ve done in M&A, it’s not yet up to that 50% number, so there is still going to be more acquisitions that we’re going to pursue. Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, China, Southeast Asia, and Southeastern Europe, were specifically mentioned in our call at the time when we did the Investor Conference. So, clearly, Brazil was on the radar screen, whether in reality then our desires can be transformed into actual actions of course is always a little bit of an uncertainty, but clearly this didn’t come out of the blue. Our acquisition in Brazil has been on the drawing board for a quite while and clearly was included in our objectives.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: As a quick follow-up, you mentioned you’re going to run more fully in the fourth quarter in North America this year than last year. Is that because you are low on inventory now or you will be building inventory because I don’t gather you’re going to see higher volumes?

componenttextpreview: I think the result is really from what we did last year. We really hit the brakes with both legs last year in the fourth quarter because of the demand pattern at that point in time and our inventories that we had. So, the differentiation is not so much be
componenttext: I think the result is really from what we did last year. We really hit the brakes with both legs last year in the fourth quarter because of the demand pattern at that point in time and our inventories that we had. So, the differentiation is not so much because of changing demands, the differentiation is because how we entered into the quarter with inventory levels last year versus this year.

What does the pipeline look like for you with M&A opportunities there and how should we expect this to evolve, is it going to be the one-off small footprint acquisitions or is there a big step up that you are likely to see in China?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, as I had indicated in the early part of this year there are about 600 glass manufacturers in China, and we have tapped maybe about 60 or so that really would be of sufficient size to at least hit our radar screen and be included in our target, I bel
componenttext:
Rich, as I had indicated in the early part of this year there are about 600 glass manufacturers in China, and we have tapped maybe about 60 or so that really would be of sufficient size to at least hit our radar screen and be included in our target, I believe. It is quite obvious given the distributed capacities that exist in China that any progress in acquisitions will be these onesies and twosies that we have to go through. There is not a big consolidated operator at this point in time and place. I think the largest manufacturer may perhaps just be one or two percentage points from our market share as far as consolidated share is concerned.
So, it’s going to be quite a number of acquisitions to eventually get to the targets that we have set ourselves. You also know that within China, we have talked about four or five regions that we want to be focusing on because that’s really where the demand and the emerging middle class is concentrated, so it makes a lot of sense to not try to be present in all geographic regions of China.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow-up in terms of the 2012 target net, half of it coming from acquisitions. It looks like in terms of purchase price a dollar of sales cost you a little bit more than a dollar, your acquisitions something up versus about $1 billion ove
componenttext: And then just a follow-up in terms of the 2012 target net, half of it coming from acquisitions. It looks like in terms of purchase price a dollar of sales cost you a little bit more than a dollar, your acquisitions something up versus about $1 billion over that time period. Al or Ed, is that going to be mostly financed by debt or are you looking at any other sources of funds for that?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: We’ve really been looking at it to finance by debt and free cash flow which is why we’ve been highlighting our leverage ratio as a sort of a barometer of where we are and how we’re going to be deploying our cash.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Al, I was curious if you could comment on the competitive landscape as you see it, especially among some of your smaller competitors in some of the regions. Are there signs of stress that are potentially creating opportunities for O-I, and possibly on a r
componenttext: Al, I was curious if you could comment on the competitive landscape as you see it, especially among some of your smaller competitors in some of the regions. Are there signs of stress that are potentially creating opportunities for O-I, and possibly on a related note, as you think about acquisitions and strategic opportunities, do you think seller expectations are reasonable and rational at this point?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me address first of all the stress factor. I think the fact that our pipeline is full as indicative, of course, that people are looking at their role and their position in the marketplace and are coming to some conclusions that are different than they
componenttext:
Let me address first of all the stress factor. I think the fact that our pipeline is full as indicative, of course, that people are looking at their role and their position in the marketplace and are coming to some conclusions that are different than they may have reached a year or two years ago. So, clearly, some companies are a bit stressed at this point in time, but that very often is not really due to market conditions as much more due to financing structures that they have elected over the past. So, that I think really explains a little bit that the pipeline is rather full at this point in time.
With regard to the seller expectations that of course is always the part of the discussion that takes the longest, because even though they have reached the conclusion that they possibly want to sell because they have understood that market conditions are changing or their own financial strength has changed. But they are still, of course, trying to tie the value to where the business was three years ago, and that is candidly where we have talk in downfall. Our position when we look at acquisitions really as how quickly can we influence the operations and generate additional efficiencies which is a significant part of the transaction value that we are willing to consider.
The other part is, is it just the consolidation game or is it a consolidation and growth game which, of course, creates a different dynamic for the business. That, of course, would also flow into the valuation that we’re going to do and then you see huge differences from region-to-region and the overall profit developed it’s quite obvious that what we did in brazil is a very highly profit generating and growing organization, say would typically be willing to put a higher value to that than in other markets where it’s just a consolidation game and where the only benefit you could get would be efficiencies.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s a very helpful. As a follow on can you just elaborate on the price mix being flat in the quarter and expectation flat in the fourth quarter, despite the volume, the pricing versus volume strategy. Is part of this a function of formula pricing of
componenttext: That’s a very helpful. As a follow on can you just elaborate on the price mix being flat in the quarter and expectation flat in the fourth quarter, despite the volume, the pricing versus volume strategy. Is part of this a function of formula pricing of pass-throughs lower cost, and as cost go back up that that would reverse or is there something else going on that you can comment on price and mix?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It varies by region. Number one, in United States, of course, a significant portion of the volatility with regard to inflation in raw materials has been taken out to the new contract stipulation, so you see pass-through provisions. So, that is really not
componenttext:
It varies by region. Number one, in United States, of course, a significant portion of the volatility with regard to inflation in raw materials has been taken out to the new contract stipulation, so you see pass-through provisions. So, that is really not going to create pressure points, but it’s going to create some variability from quarter-to-quarter with regard to price evolution. In the other parts of the world what you’re seeing largely is also geographic mix. As we’re growing much faster in Latin America where prices tend to be higher than for instance in some of the other regions in Eastern Europe that of course, is going to influence the average price as well.
So, I would say you really get a true picture and a valid picture of our pricing if you put the pricing in relation to the inflation that we’re discussing. I think that really is where you get a complete picture of the potential impact of pricing. Just looking at pricing by itself may be misleading.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. Thank you.
componenttext: Very helpful. Thank you.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you mentioned in your opening comments Al that you started to see volumes improve a little bit in North America. Could you maybe give us some more color as to what is driving that and if you think that will continue over the course of 4Q?
componenttext: I think you mentioned in your opening comments Al that you started to see volumes improve a little bit in North America. Could you maybe give us some more color as to what is driving that and if you think that will continue over the course of 4Q?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Of course, a lot of the volume in North America is really driven by what’s happening in our customer base and with the demand that they have, and I think there have been quietly a significant series of articles and analysis being done about the beer ind
componenttext:
Of course, a lot of the volume in North America is really driven by what’s happening in our customer base and with the demand that they have, and I think there have been quietly a significant series of articles and analysis being done about the beer industry, which in the United States still has 50%, 60% of volumes, and what you are seeing and what we’re hearing from the brewers is basically that, first of all, we saw clearly at the end of last year and beginning of this year a significant shift to value brands. Now, the brewers are diminishing the differentiation in pricing between value brands and premium brands to push demand back up into the premium sectors, because that apparently is a more attractive sector for them. That was also reflected in the price increases that the brewers put in place in August and in September of this year.
But what we are hearing as well is that there is now a trend where the consumers are buying more premium brands rather than value brands. We are seeing some shift there. Clearly, throughout this entire period of economic hardship, we have seen a bifurcation of the market between the lets say, age groups up to 35 and 35 and beyond and you see that reflected in microbrewers doing extremely well. You see that reflected in wine doing very well. We see that reflected in spirits doing reasonably well.
So, I think you really have a bifurcation also of some of the demand at this point in time. So, it really requires us to look at it very individualistically as to what’s happening. But, at least the comments that I am hearing is that the brewers felt confident enough in the demand cycle, that the demand wouldn’t drop off further to raise prices, and I think that’s a pretty good sign going forward.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Couple of questions for you. First, I heard you in earlier remarks that in North America profit in 2010 would be better than 2009 so that’s basically implying a huge number for 4Q. Is that a reasonable run rate to think about moving into 2011 as well as indicative of all the savings that you got coming out here?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you really go back, and that’s why I had mentioned earlier in my comments the validity of our strategy with regards to pricing. I believe in 2006 or so we were making on the EBIT line about $100 million less than we did last year on the EBIT lines de
componenttext:
If you really go back, and that’s why I had mentioned earlier in my comments the validity of our strategy with regards to pricing. I believe in 2006 or so we were making on the EBIT line about $100 million less than we did last year on the EBIT lines despite the volume shifts. When we came into this year we said at the beginning of this year that we would expect the absolute profitability of North America to be equal to the profitability that we had achieved in the previous year despite the impending volume impact that we were going to see from the pricing.
So I think for us, overall, this really means that the strategy that we had put in place is working and the benefits that we’re going to see in the fourth quarter in the United States again are mainly coming from what we did last year compared to this year with regard to volume utilization and manufacturing and operations where we had a very high degree of unabsorbed fixed cost last year which we will not see this year.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Yes, I think when we look at the 4Q, of course, some of the timing of the acquisitions will play differently into the fourth quarter than they did in so far year-to-date, because some of the acquisitions only took place in the last couple of months. But, I would say the underlying demand business we really what we’re trying to show over here is most probably also going to be reflected going forward. Now, with acquisition being predominately in growing markets that, of course, may skew just a little bit for us.

componenttext: Well, I think again we are not yet ready yet to say, well it’s going to happen in 2011, of course, so we’re trying to make sure that all the regions are going to grow and not only in sales but in profitability in the coming years, but we will only talk in greater specificity about 2011 in our January conference call.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say, again, energy of course is the big unknown. And then of course labor is a continuing inflation, basically throughout the world, but natural gas and oil as well as electricity are really the main factors outside of soda ash. I think that
componenttext: Well, I would say, again, energy of course is the big unknown. And then of course labor is a continuing inflation, basically throughout the world, but natural gas and oil as well as electricity are really the main factors outside of soda ash. I think that clearly we are seeing eventually then also cullet, which is the broken glass and the post-consumer glass generally moving perhaps with some delay in line with what soda ash prices is doing so it would also eventually be affected. But, at this point in time, none of the contracts have really been agreed upon. I think there is a lot of positioning still going on and we will have to see how that evolves.

componenttext: What we’re hearing from Russia is that demand in Russia has picked up, especially in the beer industry, and so that pressure is diminishing somewhat. componenttext: Good morning. My name is Angela, and I will be your conference operator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the O-I Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Ed White, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Angela. Good morning, and welcome everyone to O-I's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. I am joined today by Al Stroucken, our Chairman and CEO; John Haudrich, Vice President of Finance and several other members of our senior managemen
componenttext:
Thank you, Angela. Good morning, and welcome everyone to O-I's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. I am joined today by Al Stroucken, our Chairman and CEO; John Haudrich, Vice President of Finance and several other members of our senior management team.
Today, we will discuss key business developments in the quarter, review our financial results and discuss future trends affecting our business. Following our prepared remarks, we'll host a question-and-answer session. Presentation materials for this earnings call are also being simulcast from the company's Web site at o-i.com.
Please review the Safe Harbor comments and disclosure of our use of non-GAAP financial measures included in those materials. Unless otherwise noted, the financial results we are presenting today relate to adjusted net earnings, which exclude certain items that management considers not representative of ongoing operations. A reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP earnings can be found in our earnings press release and in the appendix to this presentation.
I will now turn the call over to Al, who will start on Chart 2.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed, and good morning. Before I discuss the results of the third quarter, I would like to spend a few minutes on the recent development with our operations in Venezuela. On Monday, President Hugo Chavez announced his intent to expropriate O-I's
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed, and good morning. Before I discuss the results of the third quarter, I would like to spend a few minutes on the recent development with our operations in Venezuela. On Monday, President Hugo Chavez announced his intent to expropriate O-I's facilities in Venezuela. Subsequently, a formal decree was issued by the Venezuelan government. 
First, I want to personally thank all our employees in Venezuela for their continued dedication to O-I during these difficult and uncertain times. Glassmaking is a highly specialized and complex industry, and plants require a great deal of expertise to run safely and effectively. We have been in constant contact with our facility managers to ensure a safe operating environments for all of our employees, and we continue to operate facilities to ensure we service our customers with products to meet the food and beverage needs of the Venezuelan people. 
This is a very fluid situation with many uncertainties. Clearly, we are very disappointed with these developments after successfully operating in Venezuela for over 50 years. We are working diligently to protect the interests of our employees, customers and shareholders, and we will provide timely updates as we gain a better understanding of the situation and can articulate our next steps. Ed will review a few of the financial matters associated with this situation shortly. 
Now turning to third quarter results. Earnings were $0.90 per share in the third quarter of 2010. Excluding the impact of currency translation, O-I earned $0.94 per share, so on a currency-neutral basis, earnings were basically in line with prior year results. 
Business conditions in the third quarter were consistent with those in the first half of 2010. Strong growth continued in the emerging markets, especially in South America, and we capitalized on strategic opportunities to expand in those attractive regions. 
Glass demand by the brewers remained sluggish in the mature markets while we saw positive growth in beer across the emerging markets, as well as in food, wine and spirit end-use categories on a worldwide basis. Globally, our shipments were down 2.4% from the prior year. This mainly reflect that lower volumes resulting from contract renegotiations that went into effect in 2010. If you adjust for the impact of those contracts, shipments were up 1% from last year which is more indicative of consumer demand trend. 
Like last quarter, a favorable regional sales mix in our fast-growing and profitable South American operations mostly offset the earnings impact of lower global shipments. 
While cost inflation was negligible in the first half of 2010, we did incur higher input costs in the third quarter. In addition, manufacturing costs in the quarter increased due to the startup of 2 new furnaces in South America and the completion of a realignment activity in North America. These activities impacted third quarter results, but the operational improvements will, of course, benefit future earnings. 
Free cash flow in the quarter was $75 million, which reflect seasonal working capital trends in our industry. We made additional progress on the execution of our strategic priorities this quarter. We further expanded our presence in South America through our acquisition of CIV, the leading glassmaker in northern Brazil. This acquisition added 3 plants in one of Brazil's fastest growing regions. 
Yesterday, we also announced the acquisition of a single-plant operation near Guangzhou, China, and this is consistent with our strategy to grow in one of the world's largest consumer markets. 
We successfully completed a euro bond offering in the quarter to help ensure that we maintain the financial flexibility we need to pursue additional strategic activities. 
Looking to the fourth quarter, we expect prices will remain stable. We anticipate demand in most end-use categories to improve over the prior year, with the likely exception of shipments to beer customers in mature markets. We expect to see increased sales in South America as a result of renewed production capacity and recent acquisitions. 
Overall, operating rates should be higher than in the fourth quarter of last year. Although it's too early to tell for sure, it is likely that the recent developments in Venezuela will negatively impact results in the fourth quarter. 
Now let's review our operating performance on Chart 3. Here, we show segment operating profit and margins for the company, as well as for each of our 4 regions. Overall, segment operating profit was $299 million and margins exceeded 17% of sales. Adjusted to reflect prior year currency exchange rate, segment profit was $308 million so on a like-for-like basis, quarterly earnings declined $9 million from last year, reflecting lower sales volume and additional cost inflation. 
Now let's review regional trends beginning with Europe. Operating profit was $113 million in the third quarter. On a like-for-like basis, profit was $123 million, down $5 million from the prior year. Consistent with the outlook provided during our last earnings call, third quarter selling prices were down modestly from 2009. 
Total third quarter European shipments increased slightly from the prior year. Shipments were nearly up 5% across most of Western Europe, which represented more than 80% of our European volumes. While glass demand for the beer segment remains sluggish, we saw strong demand in other end-use categories. However, the Netherlands, Hungary and the Czech Republic were down double digits due to lower food and beer shipments. In particular, Eastern Europe continued to struggle with challenging market conditions following the European financial crisis. 
Given slightly higher overall shipments and the very low inventory level entering the quarter, capacity utilization in the third quarter increased over prior year. Year-to-date temporary curtailments in Europe represented about 5% of total capacity, down significantly from the prior year. 
In North America, our operating profit was $71 million in the quarter, down $12 million from last year. North American shipments were down more than 10% from third quarter of 2009, continuing the trend that we have seen all year. Higher margins, however, again mostly offset the impact of lower sales volume. 
Lower shipments in the region were attributable to the renegotiation of several key customer contracts at the end of 2009, as well as a continued weak U.S. beer consumption, which was down 1% to 2% in the third quarter. However, trends have slightly improved in recent months compared to earlier this year. Glass shipment trends have gradually improved in recent months, as well as consumption of premium brands has picked up relative to sub-premium brands, and we also saw continued improvement in other end-use categories such as food and wine. 
We completed our footprint realignment efforts in North America during the third quarter and realigned our business mix with our remaining manufacturing network. As a result, we incurred additional costs during the third quarter that accounted for most of the shortfall in regional earnings over 2009 levels but this restructured footprint should drive improved earnings going forward, and we continue to expect that our full year 2010 North American profits will meet or exceed prior year results. 
Despite the recent developments in Venezuela, we remain very encouraged about the future of South America. In fact, our South American region continues to be our top performer with operating profit of $77 million in the third quarter as margins improved to 26%. 
On a currency-neutral basis, profits were $79 million, up $15 million from the prior year. Strong shipments continued across all end-use markets, especially beer, driven by new product introductions. In fact, volume was up around 20% in South America, excluding Venezuela, which was flat with the prior year. 
To meet growing demand in the region, we began production at our newly construct furnaces in Argentina and in Peru. These assets are already operating at best-in-class production levels. Strong growth also led to higher production and capacity utilization rates in South America. Our acquisition of CIV in the third quarter will further boost production, and Ed will review more details on that acquisition in a moment. 
Our Asia Pacific region reported third quarter operating profit of $38 million. On a like-for-like basis, profits were $35 million, down from $42 million last year. While higher prices essentially offset cost inflation this quarter, volumes were down mid-single-digits from last year. Like Europe, Asia Pac volume trends vary by country. 
Now starting in Australia, glass volumes were down. The strong Australian dollar, which is now at parity with the U.S. dollar, created a cost disadvantage for Australian wine exports. In addition, some of our beer business traded hands as a competitor added glass capacity earlier this year. We have one new business but it will take several months for O-I to backfill the lost volume. 
In China, our shipments were boost by the July acquisition of our new plant in Sichuan. Yesterday, we announced the acquisition of a majority interest in an additional plant near Guangzhou, China for $29 million. This acquisition complements O-I's existing operations in Guangdong, China's fourth largest glass market as a province, and we are pushing the upper limit of capacity in our manufacturing systems in China, which underscores the need for further acquisitions of investments in the future to keep up with the growth in this market. 
We are pleased with the progress at our new joint venture in Malaysia, and Vietnam. After only 2 full months, productivity rates have increased by about 15 percentage points. By continuing to integrate O-I's extensive knowledge of global manufacturing processes, we see additional opportunities to increase the profitability of this joint venture.  
And finally, we began production at our new furnace in New Zealand in October. We look forward to updating you on our progress with these strategic activities in more detail in the coming quarters. 
Globally, market conditions remained consistent with the first half of 2010. Glass demand for beer in the mature markets remain down, likely due to persistent unemployment across key demographics for beer customers. Emerging market growth was strong, and most end-use categories in the mature markets have been growing as those economies gradually recover.  And I'll discuss our demand trends in greater detail on Chart 4. 
With our year-to-date shipments down 1.3%, I've heard some concern that glass is facing structural market challenges. Now let me provide you some details why I do not believe that, that is the case. We have illustrated our year-to-date demand growth by key end-use categories on this chart.  And as you can see, O-I's glass shipments for spirits and wine, as well as beer in emerging markets, improved between 5% and 13% from last year, while food was up about 2%. However, our glass shipments for beer in the developed markets were down more than 11% from last year. As a result of this sizable decline, our total shipments were down slightly from last year in total. So the significant decline in glass volume for beer, mostly reflected our price over volume strategy over the past few years and not any large-scale industry shift away from beer and glass volume. 
As we raised prices to repair margins in recent years, we knew we would surrender some volume, and that is now fully reflected in our 2010 shipment trend. This trade-off has clearly improved our financial performance since we initiated this strategy several years ago. 
The orange bar on the chart illustrate our volumes excluding the impact of these pricing actions limited to beer customers in the U.S., Europe and Australia. Adjusted for pricing action effects, our shipments to beer customers were down 3.3% in the mature markets, which was generally in line with beer consumption trends. For example, consumption has declined so far this year by about 3% in Western Europe, 2% in the United States and 1% in Australia. 
While beer glass volumes are down, we have been working with a number of our multinational customers and other end-use categories to earn new business and we are encouraged by these developments. Therefore, excluding the impact of our pricing actions, O-I's global shipments were up 1.8% year-to-date, and this growth rate is a bit lower than we expected earlier this year, and it just shows that like many others, we have not been great at predicting the immediate future in this economic environment. However, I see no structural issues in the glass business. In fact, our business trends are generally favorable across most regions and end users.  And now I will turn the call back over to Ed.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Al. Now I will discuss Venezuela along with our business outlook at the end of my prepared remarks. Let me begin with our financial review with the reconciliation for sales, operating profit and EPS on Chart 5. Segment sales decreased $135 milli
componenttext:
Thanks, Al. Now I will discuss Venezuela along with our business outlook at the end of my prepared remarks. Let me begin with our financial review with the reconciliation for sales, operating profit and EPS on Chart 5. 
Segment sales decreased $135 million to $1.7 billion in the third quarter of 2010. As expected, price and product mix were essentially flat with prior year. As we've seen all year, cost pass-through provisions in our North American customer contracts resulted in a small impact on sales and had a negligible effect on operating profit. 
Moving to sales volume on the following line, glass shipments in tonnes were 2.4% below the prior year on a global basis, reducing sales by $40 million. These sales figures include the benefit of recent acquisitions, which added approximately 1% to our volumes. 
Finally, the stronger U.S. dollar reduced our top line by $90 million in the third quarter. This impact was due to a weaker euro and the Venezuelan bolivar devaluation, partially offset by stronger currencies in other countries. While the euro has rallied in recent months, it was still weaker than the U.S. dollar compared to the average of the third quarter 2009. 
Moving over to segment operating profit. The third quarter was $299 million, down $18 million from the same period in 2009. Since price and product mix were flat, they had no year-over-year impact on operating profit. Lower sales volumes only slightly impacted operating profit due to improved regional mix, given strong growth of higher margin business in South America. Manufacturing and delivery costs increased $21 million. We incurred cost inflation of $26 million and the startup costs penalties that Al mentioned. These were partially offset by incremental footprint savings and higher operating rate. Results benefited $15 million from other operating items as we reduced discretionary spending and benefited from a few one-time items. Finally, currency translation reduced operating profit by $9 million in the third quarter, mostly due to a weaker euro. 
Finishing with the EPS reconciliation, our adjusted net income was $0.90 per share in the quarter, down $0.05 from the prior year. As we just discussed, operating profit was down $0.07 from last year. However, earnings did benefit from favorable nonoperating items. Our effective tax rate was lower than last year, reflecting our current regional earnings mix. Also, EPS benefited from a lower share count after repurchasing 6 million shares in the first half of the year.
Corporate costs were up from last year due to higher noncash pension expense. This was partially offset by cost reduction efforts. Likewise, we reduced management incentive compensation expense to reflect current financial results. 
One comment on GAAP EPS. We incurred approximately $9 million of Note 1 charges in the third quarter, related to one-time costs and purchase price accounting associated with our recent acquisitions. 
Free cash flow in the third quarter was $75 million. As a result, the company had free cash flow positive year-to-date. Chart 6 illustrates our year-over-year reconciliation. The decline in free cash flow generation is mostly attributed to working capital and CapEx. Working capital was $843 million greater use of cash in the first 9 months of 2010. The difference is due to the significant inventory reductions we took last year that did not repeat at the same level in 2010. 
Next, capital expenditures were $198 million higher through September 2010. This difference was largely due to timing as 2009 CapEx was mostly deferred until the fourth quarter, and 2010 spending has been more evenly distributed across the year. Importantly, the fourth quarter 2009 spending spike will not repeat in 2010. 
Let's move to Chart 7 for more detail on our balance sheet and several strategic initiatives that we completed in the third quarter. On September 30, 2010, cash was $700 million, which was about $40 million, which included about $40 million in Venezuela. Total debt at the end of the quarter was $4.3 billion. Net debt was $3.6 billion, which increased by $826 million from the second quarter, primarily to fund acquisitions. 
Our net-debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 2.8x at September 30, higher than our second quarter ratio of 2.2x, again reflecting our acquisitions in the third quarter but the ratio was still within our target leverage range between 2x and 3x. 
Third quarter restructuring payments were higher than the second quarter, reflecting the advancement of our North American realignment project. Capital expenditures totaled $155 million in the quarter, which was similar to our second quarter level. 
Our 2010 capital expenditures will approximate $500 million. We have pulled back on some projects in the fourth quarter, but the weaker U.S. dollar and incremental capital on new acquisitions all offsetting this lower activity. As illustrated on the right, most of our CapEx this year is for maintenance projects, and it's within our 80% to 85% range of depreciation. The remaining capital is focused on our North American restructuring program and growth initiatives. The growth investments are concentrated in South America and Asia Pacific to keep up with increased demand. Overall, we believe our capital expenditures are prudent and in line with our profitable growth strategies. 
Also on the right, you can see our 2 largest strategic activities completed in the third quarter. The first is our acquisition of CIV in Northeast Brazil. Brazil represents the largest economy and glass container market in South America so it is key for O-I. We already have a robust business and experienced management team in the southern region of the company. The CIV acquisition will provide a strong complement to our current franchise in Brazil and will allow us to serve many existing and new customers who are expanding their operations in the northeast. 
CIV's 3 facilities will increase O-I's capacity in Brazil by 50%. O-I's total purchase price for CIV was $603 million, which included approximately $140 million for future tax benefits. The purchase price reflects a 5.8x EBITDA multiple, based on 2011 forecasted EBITDA of $80 million. We expect that the CIV acquisition will be accretive to earnings per share in 2011, and the return on investment of this business is well above O-I's cost of capital. 
The second strategic initiative was in early September. We issued EUR 500 million of 10-year senior notes at an interest rate of 6.75%. We are pleased that these bonds have been the most favorably priced offering in the European high yield market so far this year. In addition to an attractive coupon rate and a tax-efficient structure, greater euro-denominated interest expense is a natural currency hedge for our European profits. The proceeds of the euro bonds will enable further strategic and profitable growth. 
Turning to Chart 8. You see our business outlook for the fourth quarter of 2010. We have provided the usual directional guidance on the key business drivers affecting earnings and cash flow. All trends are on a year-over-year basis comparing expected fourth quarter 2010 performance with the same period in 2009. As Al mentioned, the developments in Venezuela will likely negatively impact our fourth quarter results. However, the situation is very fluid so our outlook does not include any potential impact from Venezuela. 
Now let me review each of the factors. Price and product mix. Similar to the third quarter, we expect prices in the fourth quarter to be flat with prior year levels. 
Sales volume. Clearly, we have struggled to identify the turning point with beer demand in mature markets. Beer consumption remains sluggish and has not improved significantly despite promotional efforts by our customers. Hence, we anticipate fourth quarter glass demand for beer in the U.S. and Europe will remain down from the prior year. However, we expect continued year-over-year growth in all other end-use categories. The net effect of these 2 trends is difficult to project. Depending on their relative movement, we can perceive fourth quarter sales volumes being 2% above or below prior year levels. 
Manufacturing and delivery. Higher capacity utilization should result in lower manufacturing and delivery costs compared to last year. Footprint savings should mostly offset cost inflation that is expected to be comparable to third quarter levels. 
Now on operating costs. Corporate costs will be higher than the fourth quarter of last year, mostly reflecting additional pension expense which we've seen every quarter in 2010. Also, net interest expense will increase approximately $15 million on a year-over-year basis in the fourth quarter due to higher debt to fund acquisitions. 
Furthermore, we are taking steps to curtail our spending plans, given lower-than-anticipated volumes in 2010. We have evaluated corporate expense, restructuring payments and working capital investments. We expect to reduce spending in these categories by $20 million to $30 million from our original expectations. 
Let me wrap up the discussion on Venezuela. As I mentioned, the financial implications of expropriation remain unclear. Given this lack of clarity, I will provide some information about our Venezuelan operations to give you a sense of their scope relative to O-I in total. 
First, we've been operating in Venezuela for over 50 years, serving the country's food and beverage industry. I'd like to take the opportunity to thank the more than 1,000 employees at the 2 plants for all their hard work and dedication during these difficult times. O-I has a 75% ownership interest in our Venezuelan operations, with the remaining ownership held by a minority partner. Year-to-date, Venezuela accounted for approximately 3% of O-I global sales volume. The country represented just under 5% of segment operating profits and adjusted net earnings. 
Finally, O-I's net assets in Venezuela approximated 4% of O-I's total net assets as of September 30. We intend to provide regular and timely updates on the situation as information becomes available. 
Now I'll turn it back to Al for Chart 9.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ed. Let me close with some comments on the financial targets that we introduced at our Investor Day in March of this year. Chart 9 highlights our net sales and segment operating margin goals for 2012. If you recall, we indicated our sales will g
componenttext:
Thanks, Ed. Let me close with some comments on the financial targets that we introduced at our Investor Day in March of this year. Chart 9 highlights our net sales and segment operating margin goals for 2012. 
If you recall, we indicated our sales will grow between $9 billion and $9.5 billion, and our global segment operating profit margins will expand to 16% to 18% by the end of this 3-year period. And we continue to expect that this growth will be achieved equally through a recovering marketplace and mergers and acquisitions. 
Now that we are almost 1/3 of the way into this 3-year period, we can say that we are pleased with our M&A properties. Through the third quarter, we have made 3 high-quality acquisitions, and more importantly, our M&A pipeline remains full as we work to close more deals in the upcoming quarters. 
On the other hand, the rate of our overall market recovery has been inconsistent, robust in South America and China but slower-than-anticipated in the mature markets. That said, we remain optimistic that a recovering marketplace in both Europe and North America should favorably impact the premium end-use segments that we serve. It is just going to take more time than we had originally expected but it's still likely to be achieved within our original 3-year horizon. 
As the developments in Venezuela over the past few days show, events can change rapidly, but based on today's perspective, we remain confident that we are on the trajectory to reach our 3-year targets.  And furthermore, O-I's strategic priorities remain unchanged to support those objectives.  
And now, I will ask the operator to open the lines for your questions. Thank you.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question is from the line of Tim Thein with Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question is from the line of Tim Thein with Citigroup.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question is I know it's kind of early days here but if you look out into the contract negotiations in Europe, curious as to any kind of early read you can give you into 2011? I know a competitor of yours had stated that they expected to be able to o
componenttext: First question is I know it's kind of early days here but if you look out into the contract negotiations in Europe, curious as to any kind of early read you can give you into 2011? I know a competitor of yours had stated that they expected to be able to offset any cost inflation into 2011, only said was their initial read. But I'm curious, given your commentary about how pricing did trail off in the quarter, if you think that's -- if you have similar expectations in the 2011 in Europe?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have similar expectations as well. We think that clearly and already in the course of this year as well, our ability and pricing was really tracking with what was happening in inflation. And in the beginning of the year, of course, we were still s
componenttext: Yes, we have similar expectations as well. We think that clearly and already in the course of this year as well, our ability and pricing was really tracking with what was happening in inflation. And in the beginning of the year, of course, we were still seeing some benefits of the deflation that was happening in the course of last year. But as we went through the third quarter in particular, we saw that the impact of the U.S. dollar, which at that point in time was higher than the previous year or was impacting the price of rent crude which is quoted in U.S. dollars and the conversion to euros, and it was causing inflationary pressure. I think we also are looking at what's going to happen in the supply and demand situation with regard to soda ash, which of course, is a considerable cost here. And I think everybody in the industry is seeing the same pressures, and therefore, I believe we will see a continued approach to the marketplace that is reflective of making sure that we pass through cost inflation appropriately to maintain our margins.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just quickly as a follow-up in terms of kind of near-term trends, can you comment as to how volumes, just specifically maybe in the last month of 2, how they've trended? Has there been any significant or any deviation relative to the quarte
componenttext: Okay. And then just quickly as a follow-up in terms of kind of near-term trends, can you comment as to how volumes, just specifically maybe in the last month of 2, how they've trended? Has there been any significant or any deviation relative to the quarterly trends that you gave earlier in your remarks?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Because the variations and the shipments are so small compared to the previous year, so easily in one week, you may be above the previous year, the next week, you are below the previous year, and it's really not indicative of any trend. So I would say wha
componenttext: Because the variations and the shipments are so small compared to the previous year, so easily in one week, you may be above the previous year, the next week, you are below the previous year, and it's really not indicative of any trend. So I would say what we're seeing in October is most probably along the same line what we saw in the third quarter.

componenttextpreview: First question on more shorter term, can you comment as to what productivity was within the manufacturing and delivery line item? Was it only $5 million if I do some of the rough math? And along the same line, what were the some of the one-time items that
componenttext: First question on more shorter term, can you comment as to what productivity was within the manufacturing and delivery line item? Was it only $5 million if I do some of the rough math? And along the same line, what were the some of the one-time items that you mentioned that helped operating profit in the quarter?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, on the productivity side, what we said was you've got flowing through there footprint, which is then, and I think as we've talked about, was about $15 million to $18 million. You had -- the startup penalties, where you have to light the furnace is g
componenttext: Well, on the productivity side, what we said was you've got flowing through there footprint, which is then, and I think as we've talked about, was about $15 million to $18 million. You had -- the startup penalties, where you have to light the furnace is got, it takes a month for the sand to get hot enough to be making glass, and you had that across 4 factories which was a penalty.  And then I'm going to say inflation was -- well, we talked about that being in the 20% to 25% range so those were kind of the moving parts George on that. In terms of productivity itself, obviously in run rates, we've been -- North America is at the low end of the range in the 80%, 85% range. We had South America that's basically running full, and you have Europe and Asia Pac that are kind of in the middle of that.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And that segues to my next question which is, given the relatively lower operating rates in North America, given the challenges you said you've had and we don't blame you, it's been a tough market but nonetheless in projecting when the inflection po
componenttext: Okay. And that segues to my next question which is, given the relatively lower operating rates in North America, given the challenges you said you've had and we don't blame you, it's been a tough market but nonetheless in projecting when the inflection point comes in beer, given that while it's a tougher market, thus far, the growth expansion plans haven't led yet to a commensurate move in your equity price. Are there any thoughts perhaps in further optimizing your asset base and your spending for that matter in your more mature markets?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, when we talk about operating rates in North America, of course, we still have in the first half of the year capacity that we haven't taken out so you have to take that into consideration as well. I think we have taken the steps that are necessary to
componenttext: Well, when we talk about operating rates in North America, of course, we still have in the first half of the year capacity that we haven't taken out so you have to take that into consideration as well. I think we have taken the steps that are necessary to adjust to the volume loss that we've seen through our pricing actions in late last year, and I think that has accomplished at this point in time. I believe that if I really look at my operating rates across the world, we are, at this point in time, at a level where we can still, through temporary steps, adjust our capacity to the demand levels more appropriately. I believe as well that we need to have some flex to the upside if demand picks up because the worst thing we could do is shut down a furnace permanently and then half year from now need one. You can imagine that, that does not lead to a very good return on investment. So I think we have taken the steps that are necessary for the infrastructure to be appropriately designed for the demands that we're seeing at this point in time, and we have sufficient flex to the upside to really be able to partake in some of these growth without immediate demand for a significant demand on capital.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In our North American team, George, has some furnaces that are actually cold, so they're in the denominator as capacity but the costs associated with it are minimal because we've taken the furnaces down and the people are laid off.

And I believe we have made some investments in the course of this year that we're anticipating a stronger, more buoyant market so I think we've most probably done some investments that is going to benefit us already next year, would not require additional investment.

componenttext: I think we did a buyback earlier this year. I don't think that at this point in time, we are contemplating a buyback where we, as you know, have a strategy for expansion through mergers and acquisitions. That's really where we have been looking at when we are also refinancing and when we issued the bonds in Europe. And I believe that's really the primary focus and target for us at this point in time.

componenttext: Yes, it does. The traditional comment about same-store sales, we don't think it's working for us because we are consciously reducing the stores in mature markets, and we're growing in the growth markets. So if you look back at the strategic footprint initiatives and our M&A, we've shut down 8 factories over the last 3 years in North America and Europe, and we've acquired 8 factories in Asia, Southeast Asia and South America. So what we're trying to do is put them together as you can talk about it, our global realignment moving forward.

componenttext: As you think about the 2012 targets, did you anticipate having Brazil be such a big part of your growth? I was thinking it was more China, and therefore, it looks like you're getting more of it in a more established market for you. And secondly, do you need more acquisitions to get to that level? Or is your footprint big enough to get to your 2012 goals?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we said in the beginning of this year, basically 1/2 of our growth is going to come from M&A and 1/2 from organic growth, and clearly, what we've done in M&A is not yet up to that 50% number so there's still going to be more acquisitions that we're goi
componenttext: As we said in the beginning of this year, basically 1/2 of our growth is going to come from M&A and 1/2 from organic growth, and clearly, what we've done in M&A is not yet up to that 50% number so there's still going to be more acquisitions that we're going to pursue. Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, China, Southeast Asia and Southeastern Europe were specifically mentioned in our call at the time when we did the investor conference.  And so clearly, Brazil was on the radar screen, whether in reality then, our desires can be transformed into actual actions, of course, is always a little bit of an uncertainty. But clearly, this did not come out of the blue. Our acquisition in Brazil has been on the drawing board for quite a while and clearly was included in our objectives.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got you. And as a quick follow-up, you mentioned you're going to run more fully in the fourth quarter, North America this year than last year. Is that because you are low on inventory now or you will be building inventory? Because I don't gather you're go
componenttext: Got you. And as a quick follow-up, you mentioned you're going to run more fully in the fourth quarter, North America this year than last year. Is that because you are low on inventory now or you will be building inventory? Because I don't gather you're going to see higher volumes.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the result is really from what we did last year. We really hit the brakes with full -- with both legs last year in the fourth quarter because of the demand pattern at that point in time and our inventories that we have. So the differentiation is n
componenttext: I think the result is really from what we did last year. We really hit the brakes with full -- with both legs last year in the fourth quarter because of the demand pattern at that point in time and our inventories that we have. So the differentiation is not so much because of changing demand. The differentiation is because how we entered into the quarter with inventory levels last year versus this year.

componenttext: Can you, Al, can you just talk about the strategy in China? You've made the announcement of the single purchase here. What does the pipeline look like for you with M&A opportunities there? And how should we expect this to evolve? Is it going to be these one-off small footprint acquisitions? Or is there a big step up that you're likely to see in China?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, as I had indicated in the early part of this year, there are about 600 glass manufacturers in China, and we have -- that's maybe about 60 or so that really would be of sufficient size to at least hit our radar screen and be included in our target li
componenttext: Rich, as I had indicated in the early part of this year, there are about 600 glass manufacturers in China, and we have -- that's maybe about 60 or so that really would be of sufficient size to at least hit our radar screen and be included in our target list. It is quite obvious given the distributed capacities that exist in China that any progress in acquisitions will be these onesies and twosies that we have to go through. There is not a big consolidated operator at this point in time and place. I think the largest manufacturer and may perhaps just be 1 or 2 percentage points of our market share as far as consolidated share is concerned. So it's going to be quite a number of acquisitions to eventually get to the targets that we have set ourselves.  And you also know that within China, we have talked about 4 or 5 regions that we want to be focusing on because that's really where the demand and the emerging middle class is concentrated so it makes a lot of sense to not try to be present in all geographic regions in China.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a follow-up in terms of the 2012 target net, 1/2 of it coming from acquisition, it looks like in terms of purchase price, that $1 of sales cost you a little bit more than $1 so it would suggest that you're going to continue to -- your
componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up in terms of the 2012 target net, 1/2 of it coming from acquisition, it looks like in terms of purchase price, that $1 of sales cost you a little bit more than $1 so it would suggest that you're going to continue to -- your acquisition something of worth of about $1 billion over that time period? Al, is -- or Ed, is that going to be mostly financed by debt or is there other -- are you looking at any other sources of funds for that?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've been really looking at it to be financed by debt and free cash flow, which is why we've been highlighting our leverage ratio as a sort of a barometer of where we are and how we're going to be deploying our cash.
componenttext: We've been really looking at it to be financed by debt and free cash flow, which is why we've been highlighting our leverage ratio as a sort of a barometer of where we are and how we're going to be deploying our cash.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Peter Ruschmeier from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Peter Ruschmeier from Barclays.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, let me address, first of all, this last factor. I think the fact that our pipeline is full is indicative, of course, that people are looking at their role and their position in the marketplace and are coming to some conclusions that are different th
componenttext: Okay, let me address, first of all, this last factor. I think the fact that our pipeline is full is indicative, of course, that people are looking at their role and their position in the marketplace and are coming to some conclusions that are different than they may have reached a year or 2 years ago. So clearly, some companies are a bit stressed at this point in time, but that very often is not really due to market conditions, it's much more due to financing structures that they have elected over the past. So that I think really explains a little bit that the pipeline is rather full at this point in time. With regard to the seller expectations, that, of course, is always the part of the discussion that takes the longest because even though they have reached a conclusion that they couldn't possibly want to sell because they have understood that market conditions are changing or their own financial strength has changed, but they're still, of course, trying to tie the value to where the business was 3 years ago, and that is generally where we have to talk them down from. Our position when we look at acquisitions really is how quickly can we influence the operations and generate additional efficiencies, which is a significant part of the transaction value that we are willing to consider. The other part is, is it just a consolidation game or is it a considered end growth game, which of course, creates a different dynamic for the business, and that, of course, would also flow into the valuation that we're going to do.  And then you see huge differences from region to region on the overall profitability. It's quite obvious that what we did in Brazil is a very highly profit generating and growing organization so you would typically be willing to put a higher value to that than in other markets where it's just a consolidation game and we're the only benefit you could get would be efficiencies.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It varies by region. Number one in the United States, of course, a significant portion of the volatility with regard to inflation and raw materials has been taken out to the new contract stipulations so you see pass-through provisions. And so that is real
componenttext: It varies by region. Number one in the United States, of course, a significant portion of the volatility with regard to inflation and raw materials has been taken out to the new contract stipulations so you see pass-through provisions. And so that is really not going to create pressure points but it's going to create some variability from quarter-to-quarter with regard to price evolution. In the other parts of the world, what you're seeing largely is also is geographic mix. As we're growing much faster in Latin America, where prices tend to be higher than, for instance, in some of the other regions in Eastern Europe, that, of course, is going to influence the average price as well. So I would say you really get a true picture and a balanced picture of our pricing if you put the pricing in relation to the inflation that we're discussing. I think that really is where you get a complete picture of the potential impact of pricing, just looking at pricing by itself maybe misleading.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you mentioned in your opening comments, Al, that you sort of see volumes improve a little bit in North America. Could you maybe just give us some more color as to what is driving that and if you think that will continue over the course of 4Q?
componenttext: I think you mentioned in your opening comments, Al, that you sort of see volumes improve a little bit in North America. Could you maybe just give us some more color as to what is driving that and if you think that will continue over the course of 4Q?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, of course, a lot of the volume in North America is really driven by what's happening in our customer base and with the demand that they have.  And I think there have been quite a significant series of articles and analyses been done about the beer i
componenttext: Well, of course, a lot of the volume in North America is really driven by what's happening in our customer base and with the demand that they have.  And I think there have been quite a significant series of articles and analyses been done about the beer industry, which in the United States, still is 50%, 60% of the volume.  And what you are seeing and what we're hearing from the brewers is basically that, first of all, we saw clearly at the end of last year, the beginning of this year, a significant shift to value brands. Now, the brewers are diminishing the differentiation in pricing between value brands and premium brands to push demand back up into the premium sector because that apparently is a more attractive sector for them. And that was also reflected in the price increases that the brewers put in place in August and in September of this year. But what we're hearing as well is that there is now a trend where the consumers are buying more premium rather than value brands. We're seeing some shift there.  And clearly, throughout this entire period of economic hardship, you've seen the bifurcation of the market between the, let's say, age group sub-35 and 35 and beyond, and you see that reflected in micro-brewers doing extremely well. You see that reflected in wine doing very well, you see that reflected in spirits doing reasonably well. So I think you really have a bifurcation also of some of the demand at this point in time. So it really requires us to look at a very individualistically as to what's happening. But at least the comments that I'm hearing is that the brewers felt confident enough in the demand cycle, that the demand wouldn't drop off further to raise prices.  And I think that's a pretty good sign going forward.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, if you really go back, and that's why I had mentioned earlier in my comments the validity of our strategy with regards to pricing, I believe in 2006 or so, we were making, on the EBIT line, about $100 million less than we did last year on the EBIT l
componenttext: Well, if you really go back, and that's why I had mentioned earlier in my comments the validity of our strategy with regards to pricing, I believe in 2006 or so, we were making, on the EBIT line, about $100 million less than we did last year on the EBIT line despite the volume shift.  And when we came into this year, we said that the beginning of this year, that we would expect the absolute profitability of North America to be equal to the profitability that we have achieved in the previous year despite the impending volume impact that we were going to see from the pricing. So I think for us, overall, this really means that the strategy that we have put in place is working, and the benefits that we're going to see in the fourth quarter in the United States again are mainly coming from what we did last year compared to this year with regard to volume and utilization and manufacturing and operations where we had a very high degree of unabsorbed fixed costs last year which we will not see this year.

But I would say the underlying demand is really what we're trying to show here is most while will also going to be reflected going forward. Now with acquisitions being predominantly in growing markets, that, of course, may skew this a little bit for us.

componenttext: Well, I would say, again, energy, of course, is the big unknown. Then of course, labor is a continuing inflation basically throughout the world. But natural gas and oil, as well as electricity, are really the main factors outside of soda ash. I think that clearly, we're seeing eventually then also which is the broken glass and the postconsumer glass generally moving perhaps with some delay in line with what soda ash prices is doing so also eventually be affected. But at this point in time, none of the contracts have really been agreed upon. I think there is a lot of positioning still going on and we'll have to see how that evolves.

componenttextpreview: Yes. What we're hearing from Russia is that demand in Russia has picked up especially in the beer industry, and so that pressure is diminishing somewhat. Ukraine is still in financial difficulty so there still is some free capacity there, and I think ther
componenttext: Yes. What we're hearing from Russia is that demand in Russia has picked up especially in the beer industry, and so that pressure is diminishing somewhat. Ukraine is still in financial difficulty so there still is some free capacity there, and I think there is also some M&A activity ongoing and several other facilities are still shut down. I would say the issue right now is much less an issue of operations shipping into Western Europe as it was earlier in the year. It's much more of a demand picture that is just at a very low level in some of the Eastern European countries that's creating still some pressure.
